* The ability to detect both individual particles and integrated signals enables comprehensive particle detection and analysis without prior knowledge of signal rates. 
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention describes an improved apparatus for automatically spin checking driven disc assemblies used in friction clutches. The apparatus aims to address limitations of prior testing methods, which were slow, inefficient, and lacked external indication of test results.

• The apparatus features a rigid test enclosure with a stationary ring and a movable ring. A driven disc assembly is mounted on a splined hub connected to a torque motor, positioned between the two rings.

• A servo motor controls the movement of the movable ring, allowing it to frictionally engage and disengage the driven disc assembly. An electronic position sensor measures the distance between the rings.

• To test for warpage, the apparatus initially engages the driven disc assembly between the rings. The torque motor then attempts to rotate the assembly against the frictional force.

• The movable ring gradually retracts, reducing the frictional force. The apparatus senses when the assembly begins to rotate under the applied torque, indicating the point of release.

• The distance the ring moves before rotation indicates the amount of warpage in the assembly. This measurement is compared to a standard value to determine if the assembly meets specified tolerances.

• The apparatus provides automatic determination of assembly quality and generates external indications to the operator, minimizing operator error. The measurements can be stored for statistical process control.

• This invention offers an efficient and automated solution for spin checking driven disc assemblies, improving accuracy and reducing reliance on manual operations. 
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to image processing, specifically face age-estimation using contourlet appearance models (CAM).
* CAM analyzes facial features by combining shape and texture variations to estimate age.
* The method involves training a system on a database of images with assigned landmark points and known ages.
* Two aging functions are constructed: one for youths and one for adults, based on different aging mechanisms.
* A support vector machine (SVM) classifier distinguishes between youth and adult faces.
* For age estimation, a CAM algorithm extracts features from the input image.
* The SVM classifier determines whether the input face belongs to a youth or an adult.
* Based on the classification, the corresponding aging function (youth or adult) is applied to estimate the age.
* The estimated age can be provided as a single value or a range with confidence factors.
* The methods described can be implemented on various computing systems.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a matrix display device for displaying two merged images, particularly useful for simultaneously displaying images from different sources with varying definitions. This is achieved by organizing the display matrix into a mosaic of identical pixel arrangements, with a portion of pixels in each arrangement dedicated to each image. This approach preserves the definition of the higher-resolution image.

* The invention allows for flexible pixel arrangements within the mosaic. For instance, a square arrangement of four pixels could dedicate three pixels to a first, potentially monochrome, image and the remaining pixel to a second, potentially different-colored, image. Alternatively, two pixels could be assigned to each image, particularly useful for two-color second images.

* Color filters can be strategically employed to enhance the merged display. For example, in arrangements where two pixels display the second image, they can be assigned complementary colors to visually recreate the color of the first image when the second image is not present or barely visible. This is particularly beneficial when the second image only occupies a portion of the display area, such as symbols or text.

* The invention incorporates contrast enhancement techniques to improve the visibility of both images. This is achieved by attenuating the light intensity of the first image in areas where the second image is displayed, preventing the second image's colors from appearing desaturated against a light background. The attenuation function is designed to be most pronounced for bright backgrounds and negligible for dark backgrounds, preserving detail visibility.

* The invention can be implemented using a dedicated hardware architecture for improved efficiency. This could involve two controllers, each interfacing with specific pixels within the arrangements, allowing for independent control of refresh rates and resolutions for each image, thereby minimizing overall power consumption. This architecture is particularly suitable for applications requiring the merging of a high-resolution monochrome image with a lower-resolution color image.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention is a mobile identification transmitter for a vehicle security system that also functions as a payment device. 
* The transmitter has a removable payment element that can be removed to prevent unauthorized payments. 
* The transmitter can communicate with both the vehicle security system and an electronic payment system. 
* The payment element can be removed and reinserted into the transmitter housing, and a closure protects the electronic components when the payment element is removed. 
</summary>

<summary>
* This document addresses the issue of toner charge decay in imaging devices during periods of inactivity. When an imaging device is inactive, the tribo-electro-static charge of the toner decreases, which can lead to inconsistent and darker image quality upon resuming operation. The document proposes methods and apparatuses to mitigate this issue by intelligently charging the toner based on inactivity periods. 

* One proposed method involves determining the inactivity period of the device and charging the toner to a predetermined level based on the calculated decay of the tribo charge. This method may also involve predicting the next user usage based on past usage patterns and preemptively charging the toner to ensure optimal performance when the device is next used. 

* Another method involves measuring the toner charge level when the device recovers from inactivity and comparing it to a predetermined level. If the difference exceeds a threshold, the toner is charged accordingly. This ensures that the toner is adequately charged for normal printing operations, preventing inconsistencies in image quality. 
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention pertains to a rotary magnetic head apparatus that allows for precise and independent control of bias currents supplied to multiple MR heads mounted on a rotating drum. This is achieved through a control signal generator on the stationary side, a decoder circuit on the rotary side, and a current supply circuit that responds to the decoder's output signals. This setup enables the control of multiple MR heads using a single-channel rotary transformer, simplifying the system architecture.

• The invention addresses the challenge of controlling the increasing number of MR heads in high-density recording/reproducing apparatuses. Traditionally, individual bias current control for each MR head would necessitate a complex rotary transformer with numerous channels. This invention overcomes this limitation by employing a single-channel control signal and a decoder to manage the bias currents of multiple MR heads.

• A key feature of this invention is the integration of the regenerative amplifier with the current circuits, forming a regenerative integrated circuit. This integrated circuit is controlled by digital data on three lines: Data, Clock, and Chip Select (CS). This digital control mechanism enhances precision and allows for the control of various functions, including head switching, bias current setting, and gain adjustment.

• To ensure efficient head switching, the invention prioritizes the transmission of head switching signal data and MR current control signal data. This prioritization is crucial because transmitting all control data at every head switch would be time-consuming and could lead to signal loss or incorrect settings. By prioritizing essential data, the invention guarantees timely and accurate head switching.

• The invention also enables bidirectional communication between the rotary and stationary sides. This is achieved by allowing the decoder to read data from the regenerative integrated circuit, re-encode it, and transmit it back to the control signal generator. This bidirectional capability facilitates the monitoring of MR head status, including the detection of faults or thermal asperity noise.

• The invention can be further enhanced by incorporating recording heads and amplifiers into the rotary drum. This integration allows for simultaneous recording and reproduction, simplifying the process of optimizing bias currents relative to recording characteristics. The recording heads and amplifiers can be controlled similarly to the MR heads, using the same control signal and decoder.

• In summary, this invention presents a novel approach to controlling multiple MR heads in a rotary magnetic head apparatus. By employing a single-channel control signal, a decoder, and prioritized data transmission, the invention achieves precise bias current control, efficient head switching, and bidirectional communication, ultimately enhancing the performance and reliability of data recording and reproduction.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention improves the process of locating and tracing concealed conductive objects, such as pipes or cables, particularly when multiple objects are close together. 
• Traditional methods struggle to differentiate between adjacent objects, leading to distorted signals and inaccurate tracing. 
• The invention utilizes a transmitter with two antennae, each emitting distinguishable alternating currents to induce separate currents in the target objects. 
• A receiver then detects the magnetic fields generated by these currents, producing an output signal based on the combined presence of both fields. 
• This allows for the identification and tracing of individual objects even when they are in close proximity. 
• The transmitter's position relative to the objects can be adjusted to optimize signal clarity and tracing accuracy. 
• Different techniques, such as varying carrier frequencies, modulation frequencies, or pulse rates, can be used to distinguish the currents induced in the objects. 
• The receiver processes these signals to generate an output, typically an audio signal, indicating the presence and location of the target objects. 
• This invention is particularly effective when the horizontal distance between the objects is less than 1.5 times their depth. 
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention describes an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network to permit hands-free automatic answering and communication. • The apparatus includes a source of power, selective switch means for connecting the apparatus with the telephone network, and a coupler for automatically coupling the telephone network to the speaker device. • Two embodiments of the interfacer are disclosed, one using an optically coupled circuit and the other using a neon lamp optically coupled with a photocell. • Both embodiments allow for automatic answering, adjustable call duration, and the option to extend the call indefinitely. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention aims to reduce the cost of undersea optical repeaters in trunk and branch ring networks by replacing them with remotely pumped optical amplifiers. These amplifiers are powered by optical energy transmitted over the same branch cables that carry communication signals. This approach eliminates the need for dedicated power cables and reduces the number of undersea repeaters, leading to cost savings.

• The network consists of a ring-shaped optical fiber cable trunk with interconnected telecommunication hubs, acting as access points for major switching offices. Branching units along the trunk allow for adding and dropping telecommunications traffic through branch fiber optic cables. These cables connect to cable stations, which serve as bilateral access points for signal wavelengths on the trunk.

• The invention leverages the branch fiber optic cables to transmit optical energy at a wavelength different from the signal wavelength. This energy powers an optical amplifier located within the branch cable, trunk, or branching unit, eliminating the need for conventional repeaters.

• A similar arrangement at the telecommunications hub enables optical energy transmission along the trunk, providing power for signal amplification from a remote location. This hub-based remote pumping further reduces the reliance on undersea repeaters.

• The proposed network offers several advantages, including enhanced survivability due to its ring topology and branch structure. A single trunk cut maintains connectivity, while branch cuts only isolate the corresponding station without affecting the ring's integrity. This design also addresses sovereignty concerns often associated with undersea networks.

• Additionally, the network allows for flexible wavelength routing schemes and can accommodate reconfigurable wavelength add/drop branching units. The use of repeaterless technology with remote pumping through branch cables significantly reduces capital, operating, and maintenance costs for communication networks.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention describes an improved cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices. The cover plate device aims to conceal unsightly mounting screws and potential electrical hazards associated with traditional cover plates. The invention consists of two main parts: an attachment member and a cover plate member. 
* The attachment member is secured to the wiring device and the electrical box using screws, featuring latching pawls and a central tab for cover plate engagement and removal. The cover plate member, devoid of any through-holes for fasteners, includes a ridge along its rear periphery and saw-tooth shaped racks on its inner top edge to interlock with the attachment member's latching pawls. 
* This design allows for secure attachment without visible screws and enables the cover plate to conform to uneven wall surfaces. The bottom edge of the cover plate houses a slot for inserting a tool to disengage the cover plate from the attachment member when necessary. 
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a collapsible light-shielding device for screens, such as televisions and monitors, to prevent reflections and enhance image clarity.
* The device comprises multiple annular strips nested concentrically, allowing for compact storage when not in use.
* The strips can slide over each other, extending outwards to shield the screen and retracting to a covered position.
* The strips may have decreasing wall thickness towards their outer edges, enabling adjustable viewing angles.
* Hook or locking elements on the strips ensure secure folding and unfolding.
* An adapter member with a flexible design allows attachment to various monitor shapes, providing a flat surface for the shielding device.
* The invention offers a cost-effective, easily installable, and reliable solution for improved screen visibility in different lighting conditions. 
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention relates to a device and method for automatically informing a speaker to decrease their speaking rate when it is likely to exceed a rate that a listener can understand. This is accomplished by determining a speaking rate for the speaker, which is compared against a speaking rate threshold that can be based upon an estimated or known listening rate of the listener. 
* The speaker can be informed to slow down by an activation of a sensory mechanism of a wearable computing device that is designed to vibrate, beep, blink, speak a message, display a message, and the like, whenever a speaking rate of the speaker exceeds the speaking rate threshold. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention aims to provide a device for optical recording of rapid processes using a TV camera, achieving a higher picture sequence frequency. This is achieved by modifying the vertical deviation and beam suppression circuitry of a conventional TV camera.

• A cyclic counter is used to count line pulses, generating an end-of-count pulse after a predetermined number of lines (p), which is a fraction of the total lines in a standard frame. This pulse controls the beam suppression and vertical deviation, effectively scanning only a subset of lines per frame.

• The counter's counting capacity (p) is adjustable, allowing for flexible time resolution selection based on the speed of the process being recorded. This enables optimization between temporal and spatial resolution.

• The device can be used with a conventional TV receiver, although the resulting image would display a narrow band of active lines. Preferably, the video signals are digitized for analysis and image synthesis.

• To enhance spatial resolution, multiple cameras with different line orientations can be used, with their signals correlated by a computer. This allows capturing information from different spatial perspectives.

• The invention offers a cost-effective alternative to high-speed film cameras, particularly for applications requiring immediate computer analysis of the recorded processes, such as in IR, UV, or X-ray imaging.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention aims to extend the lifespan of existing network equipment by enabling multimedia capabilities on legacy customer premises equipment and network elements. This is achieved through the concept of "blended calls," which combine voice and multimedia communication within a single session. To facilitate this, a telephony server or multimedia server directs calls to specialized "blender" software.

• The blender software initiates parallel voice and multimedia components for each call, establishing connections with the appropriate customer premises equipment. The voice session may be routed through the telephony server, but with an indication that it has undergone blended processing to prevent infinite looping.

• The blender software plays a crucial role in managing the signaling paths of both the voice and multimedia components. In one embodiment, it merges these signaling paths into a single path, which is then passed to the multimedia server as a single session. This unified signaling path allows the multimedia server to control the bearer paths of both components efficiently.

• The use of the Session Initiation Protocol (SIP) in this system is particularly advantageous as it provides the multimedia server with valuable information. This includes the Uniform Resource Locators (URLs) of the call endpoints, the capabilities of the clients involved, and other data relevant for call disposition handling.

• Incoming calls to a blended client are initially received by the telephony server, which then consults a database to determine if the called number supports blended services. If so, the call is directed to the blender software, which initiates the parallel voice and multimedia components.

• For outgoing calls from a blended client, the telephony server again checks if the client supports blended services. If confirmed, the call is passed to the blender, which sets up the necessary signaling paths for both voice and multimedia components, even if the multimedia component is not immediately activated.

• The system is flexible enough to handle both incoming and outgoing multimedia calls, such as instant messaging (IM). The blender software intelligently separates the multimedia request from the voice component, allowing for either simultaneous or delayed activation of the voice session.

• As an alternative to relying solely on SIP for triggering commands, the invention can be integrated with an Intelligent Network (IN). This allows for the use of IN triggers and commands for basic call disposition handling, while the multimedia server retains control over the signaling path for activating multimedia features during a call.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to content synchronization frameworks using dynamic attributes and file bundles for connected devices.
* The system uses a central reference point, such as a server, to manage content synchronization for connected devices.
* Client devices share contextual information, or dynamic attributes, with the central reference point to receive relevant content bundles.
* Bundles contain files organized by priority and include instructions for client devices on handling and installation.
* The central reference point can communicate with external partner systems to gather additional attributes or content for bundles.
* Client devices create a delta list by comparing local files with bundle contents, downloading only necessary or updated files.
* The system prioritizes downloading complete bundles to maintain file interdependencies and ensure proper functionality.
* Data compression optimizes communication bandwidth usage, particularly beneficial for low-bandwidth connections.
* The distributed architecture, where clients handle a significant portion of processing, enhances scalability and efficiency. 
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention aims to provide a system and method for anonymous communication between a finder of a lost object and its owner, facilitating the object's return. This system utilizes unique ID tags affixed to personal possessions, which direct finders to a virtual locale, such as a website, to initiate contact. Owners register their contact information and tag IDs on a centralized database, enabling anonymous communication through the system.

* The system allows both owners and finders to create accounts, register tags, and manage their contact information. Owners can associate their contact details with specific tag IDs, while finders can search for registered IDs and initiate contact with the owner without compromising either party's privacy. 

* When a finder locates a lost object with a tag, they are directed to a website or virtual locale specified on the tag. The finder can then input the unique ID from the tag into the system, which checks if the ID is registered. 

* If the ID is registered, the finder can choose to send a one-way anonymous message or open a case. A one-way message allows the finder to send a brief message to the owner without revealing their identity or receiving a reply. 

* Opening a case generates anonymous email addresses for both the finder and the owner, enabling them to communicate securely and anonymously through the system. The system acts as an intermediary, forwarding messages between the two parties while masking their actual email addresses.

* The system also supports multi-protocol messaging, allowing users to receive alerts and communicate through popular instant messaging platforms like AOL Instant Messenger, Yahoo Messenger, and MSN Messenger. This feature enhances communication options and ensures timely notifications for both owners and finders.

* The system prioritizes user privacy by ensuring that personal contact information, such as email addresses and phone numbers, is never directly revealed to the other party. All communication is routed through the system, which substitutes real contact details with anonymous identifiers.

* Overall, the present invention offers a secure, efficient, and user-friendly solution for facilitating the return of lost objects while protecting the privacy of both owners and finders. By leveraging unique ID tags, a centralized database, and anonymous communication channels, the system streamlines the process of reuniting owners with their lost possessions.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention relates to electron multipliers, particularly those used in photomultipliers and particle detectors like channel electron multipliers and microchannel plates. These devices are widely employed in electron spectrometers, mass spectrometers, and photonic detectors. 
* Conventional electron multipliers typically consist of discrete dynode multipliers or continuous electron multipliers. Discrete dynode multipliers use a series of dynodes to amplify an electron cascade, while continuous electron multipliers, such as microchannel plates (MCPs), employ high-resistivity glass channels or tubes as continuous dynodes. 
* The present invention introduces a foil electron multiplier that utilizes a series of thin, in-line foils to generate secondary electrons. This design offers several advantages over conventional multipliers, including higher gain per stage, simpler fabrication, lower cost, larger area coverage, and intrinsic rejection of ion feedback. 
* The foil electron multiplier operates by applying a voltage to each foil, creating an electric field gradient that accelerates secondary electrons through the foils. Incident particles, such as electrons, ions, or photons, transit through the first foil, generating secondary electrons. 
* These secondary electrons are then accelerated to the next foil, where they generate more secondary electrons, resulting in an electron avalanche that is collected at an anode. The gain of the foil electron multiplier is determined by factors such as electron transmission through the foils, transmission through any support grids, and the secondary electron emission yield of the foil material. 
* The foil electron multiplier design offers a higher gain per stage compared to conventional multipliers due to the efficient transmission of primary electrons through the foils and the generation of secondary electrons at the exit surface. This higher gain efficiency translates to fewer required stages for a given amplification level. 
* Ion feedback, a common issue in continuous electron multipliers, is effectively eliminated in the foil electron multiplier. Ions generated at a foil stage cannot penetrate back to the previous stage, preventing the generation of spurious electron avalanches. 
* The preferred embodiment of the foil electron multiplier utilizes thin carbon foils with a support grid for structural integrity. The applied voltage per stage is optimized to maximize electron transmission and secondary electron emission yield. 
* Experimental results demonstrate the superior performance of the foil electron multiplier, exhibiting higher gain efficiency compared to conventional microchannel plate detectors. The invention offers a promising alternative for electron multiplication in various applications, including photomultiplier tubes, particle detectors, and imaging devices. 
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention relates to a system called the 3-D Phenomenoscope, which enhances the viewing experience of motion pictures by creating a 3-dimensional effect. It achieves this by leveraging the Pulfrich effect, where lateral motion in a movie appears 3D to the viewer.

* The 3-D Phenomenoscope consists of specialized glasses with individually controllable lenses, digital photo sensors, a computer processor, and a lens control algorithm. The digital sensors capture the motion picture frames, which are then processed by the algorithm to identify synchronization events.

* The lens control algorithm analyzes successive frames to detect lateral motion and its direction. Based on this analysis, it sends signals to control the darkening state of the left and right lenses, creating the Pulfrich effect.

* The preferred embodiment utilizes liquid crystals for the lenses, which change transparency based on the applied electric current. When no current is applied, the lenses remain clear, allowing light to pass through unhindered.

* A digital sensor, similar to those found in digital cameras, captures the light from the motion picture and converts it into digital pixel values. These values are then stored in a digital pixel array for further processing.

* The heart of the 3-D Phenomenoscope is a miniature, special-purpose computer that processes the digitized images and executes the lens control algorithm. This algorithm identifies synchronization events by detecting the presence, direction, and speed of lateral motion.

* The preferred embodiment employs an intensity edge map algorithm to detect motion. This algorithm identifies and tracks the movement of prominent vertical edges in successive frames, determining the direction and speed of lateral motion.

* The 3-D Phenomenoscope offers several advantages over traditional 3D movie systems. It eliminates the need for special filming or projection equipment, works with various film and digital formats, and reduces eyestrain by activating the 3D effect only during scenes with sustained lateral motion.

* Overall, the 3-D Phenomenoscope provides a novel and improved method for experiencing 3D effects in motion pictures, enhancing the viewing experience without requiring modifications to existing film production or distribution processes. 
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention details a method and apparatus for dicing semiconductor wafers using pressure instead of a traditional wafer saw. The process involves forming trenches along the scribe lines of a semiconductor wafer, which already has individual dies fabricated on it.  After trench formation, mechanical pressure is applied to the back of the wafer, causing a clean break along the weakened scribe lines. This method eliminates the need for a saw blade and reduces potential damage to the dies.

• The process begins by forming trenches along the scribe lines using photolithography and etching techniques. The depth of the trenches can vary depending on the desired thickness of the final die, with typical depths ranging from 10% to 50% of the wafer thickness.  The wafer can undergo an optional back-grinding process to further reduce its thickness, which is particularly beneficial for applications requiring small and portable dies.

• After trench formation, an adhesive tape, such as Nitto tape, is applied to the back of the wafer. The wafer is then placed face down on a soft pad, and mechanical pressure is applied to its back surface. This pressure can be applied in the X and Y directions or in a circular motion using tools like a roller or squeegee. The applied pressure causes the wafer to break cleanly along the trenches, effectively separating the individual dies.
</summary>

<summary>
* Field-emission displays (FEDs) offer advantages over LCDs like higher contrast and lower power consumption, but they face challenges like ion damage to field emission elements. These ions are generated when emitted electrons collide with gas molecules within the display.

* The invention introduces a protection structure with reduction plates (electrodes) to mitigate this issue. These plates, typically placed on the cathode, are negatively biased to attract and neutralize positive ions, preventing them from reaching the cathode.

* One embodiment features elongated reduction plates running parallel to rows of field emission elements, offering localized protection. This design can be efficiently manufactured using photolithography and etching techniques.

* Another embodiment employs a meshwork or net-shaped arrangement of reduction plates, providing comprehensive coverage against ion bombardment. This structure involves a multi-layered fabrication process with insulating and conductive materials.

* By diverting the ion discharge path, these protection structures prevent electrical surges and subsequent damage to the field emission elements, significantly enhancing the lifespan and reliability of FED devices.
</summary>

<summary>
* The present invention describes an image sensor capable of capturing images from multiple planes, overcoming limitations of prior art that could only image a single plane. This is achieved by incorporating imaging planes on the edges of the sensor substrate in addition to the conventional top surface imaging plane.

* The image sensor utilizes a P-type semiconductor substrate with a highly doped bottom layer and a lightly doped upper layer, the latter containing the image sensor elements.  These elements consist of an image sensing region and a charge collection and transfer mechanism, typically a buried-channel CCD.

*  A key feature of the invention is the use of P+ layers strategically placed between the edge imaging planes and the adjacent image sensor elements. These layers create an electron waveguide effect, guiding charge carriers generated by light impinging on the edge surfaces towards the CCDs for collection.

* Charge carriers generated at the edge imaging planes diffuse laterally within the substrate due to the absence of a local depletion region. The P+ layers act as barriers, preventing the carriers from diffusing towards the edges and instead guiding them towards the centrally located CCDs.

*  The invention offers improved charge collection and reduced crosstalk in a second embodiment by extending the lightly doped N-type regions of the edge CCDs to the edges of the substrate. This effectively expands the lateral reach of the depletion region, enhancing the collection of charge carriers.

*  The design allows for flexible mounting arrangements, with bond pads shifted to the ends of the sensor to avoid interference with the imaging surfaces. Opaque coatings on the die edges further mitigate the impact of stray light.

* The invention's multi-plane imaging capability enables applications such as simultaneous imaging of opposing surfaces, surface imaging of passageways, and single-pass color scanning using color filters on different imaging planes. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention focuses on power management in home networks, particularly addressing the challenge of reducing energy consumption without compromising network performance. A key aspect is the ability to transfer network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device, allowing the master device to enter a low-power state. This transfer mechanism ensures continuous network operation even when the primary master device is inactive.

• The described home network operates on a master/slave architecture, where devices can function as either a network master or a slave. The network master node is responsible for administrative tasks like beacon transmission, device management, and bandwidth allocation. These functions require significant processing power, making it energy-intensive for a master node to remain active when not performing its primary device function.

• To address this, the invention introduces a method for transferring network administrative functions from a master device to a slave device. When a master device intends to enter a power-saving mode, it initiates a transfer request to active slave devices. This request serves as a solicitation for capable devices to take over the master role.

• Upon receiving the transfer request, slave devices evaluate their ability to assume the master role. They respond with a request reply message, indicating their willingness to accept the transfer. This message can also convey information about the slave device's capabilities, such as network visibility or processing power.

• The master device then selects the most suitable slave device based on predetermined criteria. These criteria can include the slave device's network visibility, intelligence, functional capabilities, or even user-defined preferences. This selection process ensures that the most capable device assumes the master role.

• Once a slave device is selected, the master device transfers the necessary data for performing network administrative functions. This data may include information about registered devices, network addresses, bandwidth allocation, and other relevant parameters. After the transfer, the original master device enters power-saving mode.

• The selected slave device, now acting as the new master, takes over the network administrative functions. It continues to manage network traffic, handle device communication, and perform other tasks essential for maintaining network operation. This seamless transition ensures uninterrupted network connectivity.

• The invention also addresses scenarios where no slave device responds to the transfer request. In such cases, the master device may wait for a predetermined period or employ alternative mechanisms to maintain network functionality. This could involve self-promotion of a suitable slave device or activation of a backup master node.

• Overall, the invention provides an efficient and flexible solution for power management in home networks. By enabling the

<summary>
• The invention describes an antenna array for measuring the direction of electromagnetic radiation, particularly at low elevation angles where ground reflections pose challenges for conventional systems. The array utilizes multiple equi-spaced linear triplets of antenna elements arranged perpendicular to a ground plane. Each triplet comprises three antennas (A, B, and C) with specific spacing (d) and height (h) above the ground plane.

• The array operates by exploiting the phase and amplitude differences of signals received or transmitted by the antenna elements within each triplet. By combining and processing these signals, a quotient signal independent of the ground reflection coefficient (p) but dependent on the elevation angle (θ) can be derived for each triplet.

• The use of multiple triplets with different spacings and heights allows for unambiguous angle measurements over a wider range of elevation angles. Each triplet is optimized for a specific angular sector, and by comparing and averaging the measurements from all triplets, accurate and reliable elevation angle estimations can be obtained.

• The antenna array can operate in both receive and transmit modes. In the receive mode, the array can determine the elevation angle of a remote source, such as an aircraft. In the transmit mode, the array can encode angular information into the transmitted signals, enabling a remote receiver to determine its elevation angle relative to the array.

• The invention provides a practical solution for applications requiring accurate elevation angle measurements, particularly at low elevations. One such application is in secondary surveillance radar systems used for monitoring aircraft altitude during landing approaches.

• In this application, the array can be integrated with a directional interrogator that determines the range and identity of the aircraft. The elevation measurement system is then triggered to measure the elevation angle of the identified aircraft, providing comprehensive positional information.

• The described embodiment utilizes three triplets optimized for different elevation angles, enabling unambiguous measurements up to 7 degrees with high accuracy and resolution. The antenna elements are strategically positioned to minimize ground obstruction and maintain a practical overall height.

• Signal processing techniques, such as superheterodyne receivers and square-law detectors, are employed to extract the relevant phase and amplitude information from the received signals. A divider circuit measures the quotient of the processed signals, providing a direct indication of the elevation angle.

• The invention offers several advantages over conventional direction-finding systems, including improved accuracy at low elevation angles, reduced susceptibility to ground reflections, and the ability to operate in both receive and transmit modes.

• The use of multiple triplets with optimized parameters enhances the system's robustness and reliability, enabling accurate and unambiguous

<summary>
• The invention improves upon prior art subminiature lamp assemblies that suffer from short lifespans due to adhesive degradation, thermal cycling, and moisture ingress. These issues are addressed by employing a high-temperature polymer, preferably a fluoroelastomer, to encase the glass envelope and base of the lamp. This design forms a robust, liquid-tight seal that extends the axial length of the lamp, enhancing its durability and reliability.

• The polymeric seal support offers several advantages over conventional adhesives and O-rings. It provides superior heat resistance, chemical inertness, and ease of handling during assembly. Moreover, the elastomeric nature of the material allows for a tight, conforming seal that effectively prevents moisture and contaminants from reaching the lamp's internal components.

• The invention also addresses the issue of heat dissipation in subminiature lamps. The polymeric seal support acts as an insulator, reducing heat transfer from the glass envelope to the metal base and surrounding components. This feature minimizes the risk of burns to users and protects sensitive equipment from excessive heat exposure.

• The polymeric seal support can be molded or machined to accommodate various lamp and base configurations. Its flexibility allows for a secure fit around the glass envelope, ensuring a consistent and reliable seal. Additionally, the material can be formulated with specific properties, such as color coding or electromagnetic absorbance, to meet specific application requirements.

• The use of a potting material, such as silicone, further enhances the lamp's performance and longevity. By filling the cavity within the base, the potting material minimizes air volume, reducing the potential for pressure buildup and moisture ingress during thermal cycling. This added protection safeguards the electrical contacts and extends the lamp's operational lifespan.

• The invention's design simplifies the assembly process and improves the overall quality of the seal. The elimination of adhesives allows for precise centering of the glass envelope within the base, enhancing the lamp's optical performance. Furthermore, the single-point sealing mechanism provided by the polymeric seal support reduces the risk of leaks and simplifies manufacturing.

• The invention's benefits extend beyond medical subminiature lamps. Its robust design, superior sealing capabilities, and resistance to heat and chemicals make it suitable for a wide range of applications where reliability and longevity are paramount. Examples include automotive lighting, aerospace illumination, and industrial inspection equipment.

• The invention's core principles can be adapted to various lamp sizes and configurations. The length of the polymeric seal support, the choice of elastomer material, and the use of potting materials can be tailored to meet

<summary>
• This document outlines a novel technique for configuring a Generalized Decision Feedback Equalizer (GDFE) based precoder in MU-MIMO wireless systems. This technique significantly reduces computational complexity without compromising system capacity, making it suitable for practical, high-speed communication systems.

• Traditional GDFE precoder design relies on the computationally expensive calculation of the "Least Favorable Noise" covariance matrix (Szz). This invention introduces alternative methods that bypass the need for Szz, thereby reducing computational burden.

• The proposed technique offers a unified framework for GDFE precoder realization, eliminating the need for channel reduction in cases where the downlink channel's input covariance matrix (Sxx) is rank deficient. This streamlines the precoder configuration process.

• A key innovation is the novel expression for the feedforward filter matrix (F) in relation to the interference pre-cancellation matrix (G). This relationship simplifies the computation of these matrices and contributes to the overall efficiency of the precoder.

• The document provides detailed numerical examples to illustrate the computation of various matrices involved in the GDFE precoder design. These examples demonstrate the practicality and effectiveness of the proposed technique in different scenarios.

• The invention's ability to enhance spectral efficiency in MU-MIMO systems while maintaining manageable computational costs makes it particularly valuable for high-speed digital communication applications, including 4G/5G cellular networks and wired communication systems. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a heat-dissipating device, specifically an axial fan, designed to improve heat dissipation efficiency. The design focuses on increasing the intake airflow rate without requiring modifications to the existing assembly process with other components. This is achieved by strategically modifying the fan housing to optimize airflow.

• The conventional fan housing, typically rectangular, limits the intake airflow area and restricts the design of the fan blades. This limitation hinders the fan's ability to effectively draw in air, thereby affecting its cooling capacity. The invention addresses this issue by introducing a novel housing design.

• The key feature of the invention is the radially outward extension of the housing sidewall at the air inlet. This expansion significantly enlarges the intake area, allowing for a greater volume of air to be drawn into the fan. Consequently, the fan blades can also be enlarged, further enhancing the airflow rate and heat dissipation efficiency.

• The sidewall extension can be implemented in various configurations, including symmetrical outward extensions, frustum-conical or frustum-elliptically conical shapes, and even partial cut-offs to form notches for improved lateral airflow. These variations provide flexibility in adapting the design to different spatial constraints and optimize airflow intake from various directions.

• The invention also incorporates an inclined portion on the housing sidewall, effectively concentrating the airflow towards the center. This focused airflow is particularly beneficial when the fan is used in conjunction with a heat sink, as it directs the cooling air stream towards the hottest point of the heat sink, maximizing heat dissipation.

• The invention seamlessly integrates with existing systems and heat dissipation elements without requiring any assembly modifications. This compatibility ensures easy adoption and implementation in various electronic devices, such as computers, where efficient heat dissipation is crucial.

• Overall, the invention provides a simple yet effective solution to enhance the heat dissipation performance of axial fans. By strategically modifying the housing design, the invention significantly increases the intake airflow rate, optimizes airflow direction, and ultimately improves the cooling efficiency of the fan.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention describes an electroluminescent display panel capable of displaying different colors based on the applied voltage. The panel consists of a glass substrate, first and second electrode layers in a matrix pattern, and first and second luminescent layers. The first luminescent layer emits green light, while the second luminescent layer emits orange light.

* The panel achieves color variation by controlling the driving voltage. At a low voltage, only the first luminescent layer is activated, resulting in a green display. At a higher voltage, both luminescent layers are activated, producing a lemon color due to the mixing of green and orange light.

* The invention eliminates the need for an intermediate electrode, simplifying the panel structure and reducing manufacturing costs. This is achieved by strategically overlapping the first and second luminescent layers, creating single and double layer portions with different threshold voltages.

* The color purity of the display can be further adjusted by modifying the width or thickness of the second luminescent layer. Additionally, color filters can be incorporated to achieve a wider range of display colors.

* The invention offers a cost-effective solution for applications requiring color-changing displays, such as automotive instrument panels. The ability to switch between green for nighttime and a brighter lemon color for daytime enhances visibility and driver comfort. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The patent describes a portable communication terminal for internet/network telephony, emphasizing its low cost and flexibility. The terminal utilizes a standardized internet protocol, like TCP/IP, to handle data transmission and reception, enabling communication with various devices and networks. This design eliminates the need for specialized equipment, promoting wider accessibility and ease of use. 
• Two preferred embodiments are presented: an ear telephone and a headset. Both prioritize discreetness, compactness, and hands-free operation. The system leverages a service server to manage user information, facilitate connections, and potentially offer additional services like news, voicemail, and chat functionalities. 
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention describes a method for fabricating a structure useful in semiconductor circuitry by using a non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide layer as a buffer layer between a semiconductor substrate and a Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide. A germanium layer is preferably epitaxially grown on the semiconductor substrate, and the buffer layer is grown on the germanium layer to prevent the formation of a low dielectric layer. 

• The non-Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide layer acts as a diffusion barrier, preventing the diffusion of Pb and Bi into the semiconductor substrate, and also acts as a nucleation layer for the Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric constant oxide. This structure is useful in various semiconductor applications, including capacitors, MOS transistors, and memory cells. 
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention aims to improve receiver input circuits by reducing signal distortion caused by non-linear components, while maintaining good small-signal performance and using standard components. This is achieved by using multiple amplification control loops to protect sensitive components from overloading.

* The first control loop, located at the preamplifier output, prevents overloading of the mixer stage and varactor diodes in the tunable network. It operates over the entire transmission bandwidth and activates at a signal level below the mixer's modulation limit.

* The second control loop, situated at the mixer stage output, protects the mixer and oscillator from strong desired and undesired signals. Its bandwidth is narrower than the first loop but wider than the intermediate frequency filter, and it activates at a lower signal level.

* A third control loop, integrated into the intermediate frequency amplifier, further enhances protection by operating with an even narrower bandwidth and lower response threshold. It can also dynamically adjust its threshold based on the second loop's control signal.

* The control loops utilize PIN diodes for signal attenuation, offering advantages such as minimal distortion, constant operating current during control, and protection against high-voltage surges. Rectifier circuits used for signal detection are carefully designed to minimize distortion.

* The input network can be further enhanced with additional PIN diodes and reactance elements to achieve greater control range and selectivity. The control mechanism exploits negative current feedback to amplify the control effect without significantly increasing noise.

* The invention also addresses the challenge of aligning tunable networks using varactor diodes. Separate voltage supplies and adjustment mechanisms allow for iteration-free alignment of all tuned circuits, ensuring optimal performance across the entire tuning range.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention simplifies the setup of collaborative workspaces between physically distant individuals during a phone call, eliminating the complex procedures common in existing PC-based solutions. The system leverages a collaboration button and indicator on the phone, which, when illuminated, signals the availability of collaborative tools on the connected PCs. Upon pressing the button, the system automatically launches compatible collaboration applications on both users' computers, enabling them to share documents, initiate video conferences, and more, all while maintaining their ongoing voice conversation.

* A key feature of the invention is its ability to automatically detect and utilize existing collaboration applications installed on users' PCs. The system achieves this through a collaboration control program running on each PC, which communicates with the phone and other PCs over the network. This program identifies and compares available collaboration applications, ensuring that only mutually supported programs are launched, guaranteeing a seamless collaborative experience for the users.

* The invention is designed to be user-friendly and intuitive, requiring minimal user intervention to establish a collaborative session. The system automatically detects when a call is established and whether both parties have compatible collaboration applications. If so, the collaboration indicator on the phones illuminates, signaling the availability of collaborative tools. Users can then initiate a collaborative session with a single press of the collaboration button, simplifying the process and encouraging spontaneous collaboration.

* The invention's flexibility extends beyond traditional LAN environments, encompassing wider network architectures like the internet. This allows users to collaborate regardless of their geographical location, as long as they have network access. The system can also accommodate various communication terminals, including PCs with multimedia capabilities, IP telephony services, and even fax machines, broadening its applicability and fostering collaboration across diverse platforms.

* The invention's core functionality can be implemented in various configurations, including integration within IP phones, "one wire to the desktop" setups, and peer-to-peer architectures. The user interface elements, such as the collaboration indicator and button, can also be implemented on the PC, offering flexibility in deployment and customization. This adaptability ensures the invention's compatibility with a wide range of existing and future communication systems, solidifying its potential to revolutionize collaborative practices.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention improves the visual impact of advertising clips inserted into video sequences by ensuring continuity of regions of interest. This addresses the issue of viewers remaining fixated on the previous scene after a shot change, potentially missing the start of the advertisement.

* The method involves generating salience maps for both the video sequence before the insertion point and for each potential advertising clip. A degree of similarity is then calculated, comparing the location of salient zones on both maps.

* The advertising clip with the highest degree of similarity is selected for insertion. This ensures a smooth transition of attention from the video content to the advertisement, maximizing its impact.

* Several methods for determining the degree of similarity are presented, including correlation coefficient calculation, Kullback-Leibler divergence calculation, and Euclidean distance-based comparisons of maximum salience points.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention addresses the issue of high electrical fields and breakdown in sub-250 nanometer semiconductor devices, particularly at material interfaces. It proposes a recessed mask structure to relocate these interfaces away from high-field zones, thereby mitigating the risk of electrical breakdown. 

• The invention involves positioning a protective mask layer below the planarized surface of conductive regions, typically by 0.5 to 20 nanometers. This strategic placement ensures that the mask-cap interface is distanced from high-field points, reducing electrical stress and potential failures. 

•  The recessed mask structure offers several advantages, including reduced leakage current, lower effective dielectric constant, and minimized damage to conductive liners during processing. This results in improved device reliability, lower capacitance, and faster signal propagation in interconnect wiring. 
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention describes a novel design for an analog-to-digital converter (ADC) that can sample and downconvert a modulated intermediate frequency (IF) carrier to baseband. The Downconverting Digitizer accomplishes digitization, downconversion to baseband I/Q components, and automatic gain control for enhanced dynamic range.

* A key element is the placement of the sampler within the predictive loop, enabling the use of digital signal processing (DSP) for the predictive filter. This reduces complexity and allows for reprogramming filter characteristics to match the input signal, improving dynamic range and noise performance.

* The Downconverting Digitizer operates in a subharmonic mode, allowing the sampling clock frequency to be lower than the IF center frequency. This simplifies design, reduces power consumption, and enables digitizing higher frequency IF signals.

* An automatic gain control (AGC) loop, controlled by the predictive filter output, maintains the input signal amplitude within the dynamic range of the predictive loop. This extends the overall dynamic range of the converter and minimizes quantization noise.

* An integrated offset nuller dynamically detects and removes offsets caused by component variations and external interference. This eliminates the need for manual calibration or offline modes, enhancing the accuracy of the analog-to-digital conversion.

* The implementation example demonstrates the Downconverting Digitizer's effectiveness in a wireless telephone receiver, achieving a dynamic range exceeding 52 dB without AGC and 124 dB with AGC. This highlights its capability to provide high dynamic range and downconversion with reduced noise, surpassing the performance of traditional baseband ADCs.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention describes a novel sensor device and a method for multiplex detection of analytes using an array of nanoscale semiconductor features. The device consists of multiple sensor devices, each containing a set of parallel semiconductor nanotraces bridging source and drain electrodes, fabricated using nanoimprint lithography. This configuration enables direct electrical detection of target molecules by measuring changes in electrical conductivity of the nanotraces upon binding events.

* The fabrication process involves depositing a semiconducting active layer on a substrate with pre-patterned electrodes, followed by nanoimprint lithography to define the nanotraces. A series of dry etch processes transfers the imprint pattern into the semiconductor layer, creating the nanoscale features. This method allows for precise control over nanotrace dimensions, crucial for enhancing sensitivity and reproducibility.

* Each sensor device in the array is functionalized with a unique sensitizing compound, such as an oligonucleotide probe, enabling multiplex detection. The probes are covalently attached to the nanotraces, and their binding to specific target molecules induces measurable changes in electrical current. This direct electrical transduction mechanism allows for real-time monitoring and analysis of multiple analytes simultaneously.
</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to a method of singulating and plating semiconductor packages, which includes plating the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe in order to prevent contamination of the lead surfaces.
• The singulation process can be performed using either a full cutting or a partial cutting technique, with the partial cutting technique involving a first partial cut followed by a second partial cut.
• The side surfaces of the semiconductor packages can be formed in a variety of different shapes, such as straight, stepped, and beveled.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention relates to a dual mode mobile terminal that can selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local network (WLAN).
* The invention aims to address the issue of power consumption and connection drops when switching between WWAN and WLAN in dual-mode mobile terminals.
* The proposed solution involves gathering service information of neighboring WWAN base stations through the WLAN access point.
* This service information, including signal strength and channel information, is then used by the mobile terminal to quickly connect to the WWAN when needed.
* This approach reduces the time and power required for the mobile terminal to scan and connect to the best WWAN base station.
* The invention enables seamless switching between WLAN and WWAN, improving user experience and battery life in dual-mode mobile terminals.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention relates to a new process for manufacturing multilayered electrical components, such as capacitors and coils. The process simplifies manufacturing by eliminating several costly steps involved in conventional methods. The invention also results in higher quality and more reliable components.

* The process utilizes flexible decals as carriers for the electrical components and electrodes. Electrodes are first screen printed onto the decals in a desired pattern. Then, electrical components, such as ceramic dielectric material, are screen printed onto the electrodes.

* The decals are then precisely aligned and stacked to create a multi-layered assembly. The stacked assembly is then heated, causing the electrodes to fuse together and form the desired electrical connections.

* This method eliminates the need for cutting and metallizing individual components, which are labor-intensive and can introduce defects. The process also allows for the creation of smaller and more complex components.

* One of the key advantages of this process is the ability to embed electrodes within the dielectric material. This results in a more uniform structure and reduces the risk of delamination, a common problem in conventional multilayer capacitors.

* The process is also adaptable to the production of other electronic components, such as ferrite inductors and multilayer substrates. By varying the electrode patterns and materials used, a wide range of components can be fabricated.

* For instance, spiral electrode patterns can be used to create coils, eliminating the need for traditional winding methods. This enables the production of coils with precise dimensions and improved performance.

* The invention also allows for the integration of different types of components within a single stack. For example, resistors, capacitors, and coils can be combined to create complex circuits.

* This technology has the potential to revolutionize the manufacturing of electronic components. It offers numerous advantages over conventional methods, including lower costs, higher quality, and increased design flexibility.

* The invention is particularly well-suited for the production of miniaturized components used in modern electronic devices, such as smartphones, computers, and medical implants.
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention describes a hierarchical lattice structure composed of interconnected unit cells of varying sizes, resulting in a lightweight structure with enhanced specific stiffness and strength. These structures can be used in a variety of applications, including sandwich panel cores, blast and impact mitigation, thermal transfer, and multifunctional structures. The unit cells can be fabricated from a range of materials, including metals, polymers, ceramics, and composites.

• The hierarchical structure is achieved by nesting arrays of smaller cells within larger cells. This nesting process involves aligning and connecting the ligaments of adjacent cells, creating a strong and interconnected network. The lattice structures can be further strengthened by mating two oppositely oriented structures, resulting in a balanced configuration.

• The invention also details various manufacturing methods for these structures, including injection molding, investment casting, and lattice block construction. Injection molding allows for the creation of complex unit cell geometries using thermoplastic polymers. Investment casting enables the fabrication of structures from a wider range of materials, including metals.

• The use of a polymeric unit cell array as a template for deposition of other materials, such as silicon carbide, is also described. This process involves coating the polymer template with the desired material and then removing the polymer core, leaving a hollow structure with enhanced properties.

• The invention highlights the advantages of these hierarchical lattice structures, including their high strength-to-weight ratio, excellent energy absorption capabilities, and superior heat transfer characteristics. These properties make them suitable for applications requiring lightweight, strong, and thermally conductive materials.

• The document also discusses the potential use of these structures in various fields, such as aerospace, automotive, and construction. Their lightweight nature and high strength make them ideal for use in aircraft and vehicle components, while their energy absorption capabilities make them suitable for protective structures.

• The invention emphasizes the versatility of the design, allowing for the creation of structures with tailored properties by adjusting the cell size, geometry, and material composition. This adaptability makes these structures suitable for a wide range of applications with specific performance requirements.

• The document also mentions the possibility of incorporating additional functionalities into these structures, such as energy storage and catalytic activity. This can be achieved by coating the lattice structure with functional materials, further expanding their potential applications.

• Overall, the invention presents a novel approach to designing and manufacturing lightweight, strong, and multifunctional materials with hierarchical lattice structures, opening up new possibilities in various fields.
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention describes an integrated process for co-producing power and hydrocarbons using a combination of dry and wet gasification technologies. The process leverages the high-pressure capabilities of wet gasification for power generation and the efficiency of dry gasification for producing synthesis gas suitable for hydrocarbon synthesis. This integration optimizes energy efficiency and reduces capital costs compared to standalone facilities.

• A key aspect of the invention is the sharing of resources between the IGCC and CTL plants. This includes a shared air separation unit, which reduces the cost of oxygen production, and the use of fuel gas from the CTL plant as fuel in the IGCC facility, enhancing steam production and overall plant efficiency. Additionally, shared utility systems further contribute to cost savings and improved efficiency.

• The integration also facilitates effective CO2 capture and sequestration. By utilizing CO2 from the CTL plant in the IGCC facility's gas turbine, the final off-gas primarily consists of CO2 and water vapor. This allows for easier CO2 capture and combination with the remaining CO2 from the CTL plant, enabling efficient sequestration or utilization for purposes like enhanced oil recovery.

• Overall, the invention presents a synergistic approach to co-producing power and hydrocarbons, maximizing resource utilization, minimizing environmental impact, and enhancing economic viability through shared infrastructure, optimized gasification technologies, and effective CO2 management. 
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention improves the reliability of oxide superconducting materials, particularly at their surfaces, by addressing the issue of oxygen depletion.  The invention involves creating a blocking film over the surface of the material, effectively sealing the oxygen within and preventing its escape, especially in a vacuum. 

* The blocking film, made from materials like silicon nitride or aluminum oxide, is applied using a photo CVD method, which ensures even coating over the microscopically porous surface of the superconducting material. This process, along with heat treatment and optional oxygen injection, helps maintain the ideal oxygen concentration for superconductivity, even at the surface. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention is an apparatus and method for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination by creating precisely measured cross-sectional specimens. 
• The apparatus utilizes a clamping system to secure the foam sheet and a screw thread mechanism to advance the sheet a precise amount (0.004 inches per increment), allowing for the cutting of thin, parallel slices using a sharp blade like a razor. 
• This method preserves the integrity of the foam's cellular structure, enabling accurate microscopic examination and analysis of cell size, shape, and distribution, which are crucial for quality control and material comparison in various applications. 
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention relates to a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination with respect to the vertical assumed by a seismometer, especially an ocean bottom seismometer (OBS), and for leveling the seismic motion detectors carried by such a unit.
* The invention addresses the problem of ensuring good seismic coupling and accurate data collection in OBS operations where precise placement and surface conditions are uncertain.
* The invention provides a simple and inexpensive alternative to existing gimbal or "boat" leveling systems.
* The invention comprises a pendulum-like system with a seismic motion detector suspended at the end of a shaft protruding from a spherical ball that rests in an annular seat.
* A spring-loaded plunger, controlled by a solenoid and pin mechanism, locks the ball, shaft, and detector in their orientation after deployment.
* This design ensures a rigid connection between the detector and the seismometer frame, improving acoustic coupling and data accuracy.
* The angle of inclination of the seismometer can be determined after retrieval by measuring the angle between the locked pendulum and a known vertical reference.
* The invention also provides automatic leveling of the seismic motion detector due to the pendulum's natural alignment with the vertical.
* This invention offers a cost-effective and reliable solution for improving data quality and understanding the ocean floor topography in OBS deployments. 
</summary>

<summary>
• This invention describes a new type of relative humidity sensing element. The sensor is energized by low voltage current and is physically sturdy. It has a response time of about one second and is manufactured by a novel combination of familiar manufacturing methods. 
• The humidity sensing element comprises a first electron conductive electrode, a porous coating of dielectric thereon, and minute particles of electron conductive material deposited in the interstices of porosity of the dielectric. It also has a second electron conductive electrode pervious to moisture vapor and disposed on the dielectric coating on the opposite side thereof from the first electrode. 
• The preferred manufacturing method includes forming the first electrode from commercially pure aluminum and anodizing the aluminum to form the dielectric coating. Atomic particles of nickel are then vacuum deposited from a hot filament into the interstices of the porosity of the dielectric. Finally, the particles in the interstices are contacted by hydrolyzing and sealing the anodized coating, and nickel is vacuum deposited onto the sealed anodized coating to form the second electrode. 
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention describes a novel force transmission structure for a motor assembly, particularly beneficial for window lift systems in vehicles. This structure aims to mitigate noise and vibration issues present in conventional designs. The core of the invention lies in a unique coupling mechanism between a drive plate and a shaft.

* The drive plate features a mounting hole divided into at least three interconnected sections, typically arranged in a Y-shape. This hole accommodates a toothed portion on the shaft, also with at least three teeth, ensuring secure engagement and rotation. This design distributes the force more evenly during operation, reducing impact and vibration compared to traditional flat-surface couplings.

* The motor assembly incorporates a gear train to drive the system. A worm gear, driven by the motor, transmits power to the drive plate through a damper. This damper, often made of rubber, further absorbs vibrations and noise, contributing to the system's quiet operation. The shaft, driven by the rotating drive plate, ultimately powers the window lift mechanism.

* Additional features enhance the design's effectiveness. Buffer holes in the drive plate aid in manufacturing and reduce material stress. The use of engineering plastics for the drive plate provides strength, impact resistance, and vibration absorption. This combination of features results in a robust, quiet, and efficient force transmission system suitable for demanding applications like vehicle window lifts. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention relates to a method and system for generating a mobile time reference in a portable transceiver, particularly for WCDMA systems. The system aims to improve signal detection, identification, and monitoring in mobile environments where multipath signals are common. This is crucial for 3G and beyond wireless communication systems that demand higher data rates and reliability.

• The system utilizes a high-frequency oscillator (TCXO) and a low-frequency oscillator (CO) to generate and maintain a highly accurate mobile time reference. The TCXO provides a precise clock signal during active mode when the transceiver is transmitting or receiving data. In contrast, the CO, which consumes less power, maintains the time reference during idle mode to conserve battery life.

• A free-running counter (FRC) within the WCDMA modem serves as the core of the time reference generation mechanism. The FRC utilizes the TCXO clock during active mode to generate the mobile time reference, which includes clock phase, chip counter, slot counter, and frame counter information. This information is crucial for various signal processing tasks within the transceiver.

• During the transition to idle mode, the FRC switches to the CO clock and utilizes a drift estimator and correction circuit to maintain the accuracy of the mobile time reference. The drift estimator, based on Kalman estimation, continuously tracks the drift and bias of the CO clock, ensuring that the time reference remains accurate even during extended idle periods.

• When the transceiver returns to active mode, the FRC seamlessly switches back to the TCXO clock, using the maintained mobile time reference as a starting point. This fast wake-up mechanism minimizes the time spent in the power-hungry active mode, further enhancing battery life.

• The invention also describes a multipath signal detection and recovery system that leverages the accurate mobile time reference provided by the FRC. This system employs a multipath monitor to identify and track multipath signals and a multipath radio signal recovery circuit to recover the transmitted data.

• The multipath radio signal recovery circuit utilizes multiple single-path processors (SPPs), each dedicated to processing a specific multipath signal. The SPPs perform phase correction and timing alignment, ensuring that the signals are combined constructively to maximize signal strength and improve data recovery accuracy.
</summary>

<summary>
* This invention describes an individually fitted helmet liner that can be quickly and easily fitted to a wearer's head.
* The liner is designed to be refitted to accommodate changes in head size.
* It features a uniform structure for predictable performance.
* The liner does not require trimming after fitting.
* It is designed for simple and cost-effective manufacturing.
* The liner effectively resists shifting position on the wearer's head.
* Unlike previous designs, it does not require drawstrings for tension during size adjustment.
* The liner comprises multiple layers of thermoplastic sheets with unfilled pockets that deform upon compression.
* This design allows for a snug fit while conforming to the wearer's head shape, eliminating the need for precise alignment of layers during manufacturing. 
</summary>

<summary>
• The invention describes a multiorifice structure and a method for its fabrication, particularly for use as a spray disc in automotive fuel injectors. This structure aims to improve the atomization of fuel injected into internal combustion engines, enhancing combustion efficiency. The design addresses the limitations of prior art, such as drilling, photoetching, and tube fusion, which struggle to achieve the desired aperture size and uniformity in a cost-effective manner.

• The multiorifice structure consists of alternating concentric layers of solid rods and cylindrical members fused together. The rods in each layer are arranged at a progressively larger angle relative to the central axis of the structure. This arrangement creates a series of triangular-shaped interstices between the rods and cylindrical members, which serve as the orifices for fluid passage.

• The thickness of the structure is carefully chosen to ensure that the fluid passing through the orifices exits with a directional component parallel to the axis of the interstices. This directional control, coupled with the triangular shape of the orifices, promotes more effective atomization of the exiting fluid compared to circular orifices. The triangular shape enhances surface tension forces, leading to increased oscillation and breakup of the fluid stream into smaller droplets.

• Fabrication of the multiorifice structure involves a simple and economical method. It begins with a central core rod surrounded by twisted rods, encased within a cylindrical member. This process repeats with additional layers of twisted rods and cylindrical members, each layer having a larger diameter than the previous one. The angle of the rods in each layer can be adjusted to control the final dispersion angle of the fluid.

• To facilitate fusion, the rods and cylindrical members can be coated with a material possessing a lower melting point than the base materials. This coating, applied through methods like electroplating or vapor deposition, ensures a strong bond between the components during the fusion process.
